Here is an easy way to understand this theory:👌

Light in the train travels a longer distance(hypotenuse) than the light travels in a stationary.
So if the time is equal for both situation, Moving and Stationary, the light in the train will move faster than the light outside the train (which is not possible as it requires infinite amount of energy to go faster than light, in Einstein's formula).

So the time will have to dilate (time dilation) in the train to balance the speed of light in the train with the speed of light outside the train(stationary). Speed of light in vacuum is the constant limit.

Speed(constant) = Distance/time.

So if the light travels 100 m in the train(very fast train) and 50 m outside the train in T seconds. Then, this will cause the time in the train to dilate 2 times longer. Speed = 100/2T = 50/T and so now both have the same speed. But, now the time in the train is 2x longer( 2T : T ) than outside the train.

(I don't know if this is correct with the real formula, but this is just a way to understand the concept)

There is something called length contraction too. Instead of the time the one that is dilated. The distance will contract(reduced) to balance the ratio.

I really dislike the way things are shown here. First of all, some claims are wrong: before 1905, there was experimental both theoretical arguments (from Maxwell's equations) and observational evidences of the invariance of the speed of light (Michelson-Morley experiment), the equations of special relativity were known before Einstein (hence the name Lorentz' equations - not to mention the role of Poincaré). Einstein brought a new light on those ideas which he latter developed and a deep physical explanation but he was not alone in that quest. Also, I don't think that the explanation by Michio Kaku at 25" really helps here (but that's a detail).

But most importantly, the presentation of the reaction of the scientific community seems crazy. The new ideas proposed by Einstein surely needed some time to be accepted but depicting the reaction of Philipp Lenard as representative is wrong: many physicist accepted the theory (precisely because of the observational evidences and previous theoretical arguments). By the way, it seems that Lenard was not always that crazy (although he ended being crazy). And the idea that scientist's refused the theory because they based their career on Newtonian mechanics is wrong (electromagnetism and thermodynamics were already well established sciences); it's not exactly what the speaker says at 2'05" but I fear that it can be interpreted, given current taste for pseudo-sociological arguments, as "they refused the idea solely because their career was at stake".

Clearly not a great video (poorly presents the ideas and their impact).
